Award.AwardTitle: PHYSIOLOGICAL AND ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE FORCINGS ON CARBON FLUXES IN THE SOUTHERN OCEAN MIXED LAYER
Award.AbstractNarration:
Based on underway measurements of the dissolved O2/Ar ratio and the triple isotopic (16O,17O, 18O) composition of oxygen in surface seawater samples, estimates of two non-incubation biogeochemical proxies are to be determined on cruises in the LTER study region adjacent to Palmer Station. A measure of biological produced oxygen super-saturation can be made from the O2/Ar ratio. A separate triple isotopic determination of dissolved oxygen yields the fraction of the dissolved oxygen pool derived from phytoplankton photosynthesis. Along with a knowledge of the oxygen gas exchange coefficient, rates of net community production (NCP) and gross primary production (GPP) in the mixed layer can be estimated. Other biogeochemical parameters such as nutrients, light, mesoscale variability, pulse amplitude fluorescence (indication of phytoplankton physiological stress), plankton taxonomy (HPLC pigments; satellite imagery), along with particulate organic carbon may be used to interpret and synthesize the biological productivity terms.

Study of the Southern Ocean oxygen cycle allows a complementary view of the carbon cycle to be constructed, and in principle may serve as an independent check of the carbon budget terms in this important CO2 sink region of the global ocean. Secondly, the potential for ecosystem change may also be revealed from study of the relationships between proxies of net community production and the assemblage of Southern Ocean plankton communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When photosynthesis exceeds respiration at the ocean surface, net community production acts as a pathway for transfer of carbon from the atmosphere to the deep ocean. Organic matter produced by plankton and not respired in the surface mixed layer sinks to depth where it is isolated from the atmosphere for years or longer. This process is important in the Southern Ocean (waters surrounding Antarctica), especially at the Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP), a region that has experienced drastic changes in the last decades, including some of the highest rates of warming on record and a reduction in sea ice cover. Surprisingly, our understanding of the factors influencing NCP at the WAP is limited. As part of this project, we explored how changes in the availability of iron and light, both known to often limit photosynthesis in the Southern Ocean, translate into changes in NCP. We found that when light is limited through deep mixed layers, NCP is consistently low. When mixed layers are shallow, NCP is highly variable, presumably because of varying availability of iron and potentially light. Our results show that these bottom-up controls on rates of photosynthesis impact the productivity of the entire plankton community thus ultimately determining carbon export from the surface. We also found that the relation of NCP to plankton assemblage characteristics is more intricate than currently understood.

5 junior scientists (3 PhD students and 2 postdocs) were directly or indirectly involved in this project. Thanks to this grant, two of them had the opportunity to experience research in Antarctica. During the time period of this grant, our group published several articles describing factors controlling fertility of Southern Ocean waters, with some more specifically at the WAP. We also shared our Antarctic experiences and research with visitors at the Museum of Life and Science (Durham, NC).
